chunks.en:
In the past three years, I bought three phones: one Pixel 6 Pro and two Pixel 7a.
Current situation:
The Pixel 6 Pro, which has always been used in a silicone case, cracked in the lower left corner without any bumps.
A Pixel 7a was placed on a stool, and when I wanted to use it, I found that the screen could not be lit. adb devices showed that the device was still running normally.
I was heartbroken when I bought the Nexus 6P, so I won't buy Pixel phones anymore.

chunks.en: It's just industrial fast-moving consumer goods garbage. Semi-industrial garbage refers to ThinkPads from the IBM to Lenovo transition period, which still retain industrial modular assembly where you disassemble and replace broken parts. The Pixel era is now monolithic pure fast-moving consumer goods garbage. Early Pixel generations before the 5th generation had various serious hardware problems (these generations are still my main devices, I don't care about later Pixels, and I don't know what problems they have), but Google rushed to ship them to meet delivery goals and deadlines. Anyway, Google has free after-sales service policies overseas, but Pixel fans in China are all about tinkering and privacy, and the after-sales service here is 0.
Replying with a 6 Pro in hand, the Pixel XL is still in service backing up albums.
Buy Samsung for Android, it's worry-free and easy.

chunks.en: > Always used in a silicone case... The problem of cracking in the lower left corner lies here. My family and I have been buying Sony phones since 2018, and I don't use anything, no screen protector or case, just completely bare; the other person uses both a screen protector and a silicone case. As a result, every one of my Sony phones is intact (XZ2 â†’ Mark 3), and every one of hers has problems (XZ2 â†’ Mark 2 â†’ Mark 5; among them, the Mark 2 generation even had its screen replaced twice...). Moreover, it's just like OP described, no one provoked it, it just cracked itself. The key is that my hand trembles and twitches frequently, so I often drop things, and I don't know how many times the phone has been dropped. The sides of my XZ2 were chipped in the later stages, but the screen didn't crack. I've repeatedly advised her not to use that case, but she won't listen, and then it keeps cracking. So I advise OP to try not using a case or screen protector with your next phone to see if it lasts longer.
@chutsetien Why does using a silicone case cause cracking? What is the principle behind this? It is mainly to prevent it from falling to the ground and breaking.
@chutsetien I think it's more scientific not to use a screen protector. The screen hardness is relatively strong now, so it generally can't be scratched.

@wuruxu I think it might be related to continuous stress? Silicone cases are generally very tightly fitted to the phone, and coupled with changes in the weather, indoor and outdoor environments, and the phone's own heat generation, which may cause the silicone case to expand and contract, perhaps the phone will always be subjected to some unbalanced force? Maybe it will crack one day. Anyway, our practical results are like this, every one of my phones has been dropped many times and is fine, but hers actually cracked once right in front of my eyes, and I witnessed the whole process of self-cracking...

It's better to buy a OnePlus phone. Google's phones are all based on reference designs; the quality, performance, and localized features are all not good.

chunks.en: I've had the Pixel 3XL and Xperia 1 III. The fingerprint sensors of both phones stopped working after half a year. It's said that the Xperia's Snapdragon 888 got too hot and fried it. I don't need a fancy system, but the hardware and quality levels aren't worth the price. Especially now that Sony has cut the 4K screen, and the Pixel's CPU is weak, why are they selling it so expensively?
@zhxhwyzh14 My 6P was wasted by CPU dry soldering. The heat generation was too high, there was no heat dissipation design, and the quality control was terrible.
